contentrichtext.text: '''Enteric duplication cysts''', sometimes simply called '''duplication cysts''', are rare congenital malformations of the [[gastrointestinal tract]].<ref name="pmid12235349">{{cite journal |author=Tong SC, Pitman M, Anupindi SA |title=Best cases from the AFIP. Ileocecal enteric duplication cyst: radiologic-pathologic correlation |journal=Radiographics |volume=22 |issue=5 |pages=1217–22 |year=2002 |pmid=12235349 |doi= |url=http://radiographics.rsnajnls.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=12235349}}</ref> They most frequently occur in the [[small intestine]], particularly the [[ileum]], but can occur anywhere along the gastrointestinal tract.<ref name="pmid12235349"/> They may be cystic or tubular in conformation.<ref name="Muratore">{{cite book|last=Muratore|first=Christopher|title=General Surgery: Principles and International Practice, Vol 1|year=2008|publisher=Springer|isbn=1848001398|page=1428|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=0sdcAQLAc-MC&pg=PA1428&dq=intestinal+duplication&hl=en&sa=X&ei=xKltUdrvL5DU0gGG2YDACg&ved=0CDMQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=intestinal%20duplication&f=false|coauthors=Tracy, Thomas, Jr.|editor=Bland, Kirby, et al.|accessdate=16 April 2013|chapter=Neonatal Bowel Obstruction}}</ref> The condition of having duplication cysts has been called '''intestinal duplication'''.<ref>{{cite journal | last=Fitz | first=Reginald H. | authorlink=Reginald Heber Fitz | title=Persistent omphalomesenteric remains: their importance in the causation of intestinal duplication, cyst formation and obstruction | journal=The American Journal of Medical Sciences | year=1884 | volume=88 | pages=30–57}}</ref> ==Symptoms== Symptoms depend on the location of the duplication. Duplications occurring high in the gastrointestinal tract (e.g. esophageal) may cause difficulty breathing due to compression of the airway. Lower gastrointestinal duplications (e.g. duodenum, colon) can be associated with abdominal pain, [[gastrointestinal bleeding]], a palpable mass, vomiting, or may cause [[bowel obstruction]]. Smaller lesions can act as a so-called "lead point" for [[intussusception]].<ref name="Zahir">{{cite journal|last=Zahir|first=Israr|coauthors=et al.|title=Duplication Cyst in a New Born|journal=International Journal of Pathology|year=2010|volume=8|issue=2|pages=84–86|url=http://www.jpathology.com/Issues/IJP%20Vol%208-2/DUPLICATION%20CYST%20IN%20A%20NEW%20BORN.8.2.pdf|accessdate=16 April 2013}}</ref> ==Treatment== Duplications are usually removed surgically, even if they are found incidentally (i.e. not causing symptoms or encountered on routine studies for other reasons), as there is a high incidence of complications resulting from untreated cases.<ref name="Zahir" /> Cysts are often technically easier to remove than tubular malformations since tubular structures usually share a blood supply with the associated gut.<ref name="Muratore" /> ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://emedicine.medscape.com/article/936799-overview#showall Gastrointestinal duplications] at Medscape {{Congenital_malformations_and_deformations_of_digestive_system}} [[Category:Congenital disorders of digestive system]] {{med-stub}}
